Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that all air exhausted from an enclosed hazardous area is vented to an outdoor area that, were it not for the vented air, would be a non-hazardous area or a hazardous area that would be classified as no more hazardous than the enclosed hazardous area.

The operator must ensure that measuring devices are installed that will monitor any loss of ventilation pressure differential and any loss of functionality of each ventilation system for a hazardous area and that will, no more than 30 seconds after such a loss occurs, activate audible and visual alarms at the control points from which the system is monitored.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Positive overpressure relative to atmospheric pressure
Subsection.Text: The operator must, in respect of the main control centre and all accommodations areas on an installation, ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are maintained at a positive overpressure relative to atmospheric pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all of their external doors that provide a primary means of access to them are equipped with airlocks; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all of their other external doors are equipped with airlocks or other means of maintaining and monitoring positive overpressure relative to atmospheric pressure.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Power shut-off for mechanical ventilation system
Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the power source for a mechanical ventilation system that serves a hazardous area, a work area in a non-hazardous area or an accommodations area is capable of being shut off from the control station and from a position that is outside the area being ventilated and that will remain accessible during any fire that may occur within that area.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Inlets and outlets of ventilation systems
Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the main inlets and outlets of all ventilation systems are capable of being closed from a position that is outside the area being ventilated and that will remain accessible during any fire that may occur within that area.

The operator must ensure that any ventilation system that serves a non-hazardous area is equipped with emergency devices in the event of a mechanical ventilation failure or the detection of hazardous gas, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: measuring devices to monitor any loss of ventilation pressure differential;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: audible and visual alarms;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an automated isolation device to prevent hazardous gas from entering the non-hazardous area; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a device to remotely seal the non-hazardous area — including inlets and outlets of all ventilation systems — from the control station and from a position outside the non-hazardous ventilated area that will remain accessible during any fire that may occur within the area.

Subsection.Text: In order to prevent the ignition of flammable, combustible or explosive substances on an installation, an operator must ensure that measures are implemented to prevent the uncontrolled release or accumulation of those substances, including by ensuring that materials and equipment are properly arranged.

The operator must ensure that any system or equipment that is to be used in a hazardous area is designed to control ignition sources and to prevent fire and explosions in that area, taking into account the area’s classification under subsection 113(2).

For the purposes of meeting the requirements under subsections (1) and (2), the operator must ensure that any control measures identified in the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1) are implemented.
The operator must ensure that any equipment located in a hazardous area is rated for use in that area and is installed, ventilated and maintained to ensure safe operation.

The operator must ensure that any equipment that is operated in a non-hazardous area is operated at a safe distance from any flammable, combustible or explosive substances and is, unless it is rated for use in a hazardous area, equipped with an automatic and manual means of deactivation in the event of fire or hazardous gas detection.

The operator must ensure that any equipment that is located in a non-hazardous area and that is to remain in service in the event of an emergency associated with a gas release is rated for use in a hazardous area and is installed, ventilated and maintained to ensure safe operation.
The operator must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the gas mixture inside a cargo tank is maintained outside the explosive limits; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the systems associated with the cargo tank are designed to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: prevent fire, gas or explosion hazards during all operating modes through the use of sufficient control measures, including alarms, and through redundancies in those measures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: ensure that affected persons are made aware when the systems become impaired.

Subsection.Text: A work permit is required for all hot work carried out on an installation.
The work permit for hot work must set out safe distances to be maintained between the hot work and any well or any flammable, combustible or explosive substance.

Section.MarginalNote: Means of escape, evacuation and rescue
Section.Text: An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with a safe means of escape, evacuation and rescue, taking into account the results of the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1) and comprehensive and documented safety studies.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the installation is equipped with a temporary safe refuge that will, in the case of an emergency, including an accidental event,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide sufficient space to accommodate all persons who may need to use the refuge until they have been evacuated, the accidental event has been brought under control or the emergency otherwise ends;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: protect the persons referred to in paragraph (a) from fire, gas release and explosion hazards for as long as they are in the refuge;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide the means for communication and command and, if applicable, for the monitoring and control of the accidental event for as long as persons are in the refuge; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide signage and lighting to enable safe evacuation from the refuge.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the accommodations area, main control centre and any other area of an installation that is required to remain safe for persons to occupy during an emergency, including the temporary safe refuge, are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed to prevent ingress of hazardous substances; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designed and located to enable occupation for the time required to implement emergency and evacuation procedures.

Subsection.Text: The operator must verify on a periodic basis that the temporary safe refuge meets the requirements set out in subsections (1) and (2) and must record the findings resulting from the verification.
An operator must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in any area where persons are normally present on an installation, there are at least two exits, each connected to an escape route that provides safe, direct and unobstructed access to temporary safe refuges, muster areas, embarkation stations and evacuation points; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there are means for persons to descend to the water.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(a), if an area referred to in that paragraph has an area less than 20 m2 or is a passage less than 5 m in length, the operator must ensure that there is at least one exit as described in that paragraph in that area.

The operator must ensure that the exits referred to in paragraph (1)(a) are separated as far apart from each other as possible to increase the likelihood that at least one exit and its connected escape route will be passable during an accidental event.
The operator must ensure that the installation has escape routes on two of its sides.

The operator must ensure that all escape routes from an accommodations area or a temporary safe refuge to a muster area, embarkation station or evacuation point are clearly marked and illuminated and provided with fire protection to allow for the safe evacuation of persons in a time frame determined in the safety studies referred to in section 116.

The operator must ensure that each escape route is of sufficient size to enable the efficient movement of the maximum number of persons who may need to use it, as well as unrestricted manoeuvring of firefighting equipment and stretchers, taking into account the maximum number of persons who can be accommodated on the installation.
An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with life-saving appliances that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are sufficient in number and have the necessary redundancy to ensure their availability in any emergency situation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of the LSA Code and the annex to International Maritime Organization Resolution MSC.81(70), Revised Recommendation on Testing of Life-Saving Appliances, as if the installation were a vessel to which the Code and the Resolution apply.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that life-saving appliances can withstand all loads to which they may be subjected when they are in use.

The operator must ensure that, in determining the number of persons any lifeboat, life raft or marine evacuation system can accommodate, the persons’ space requirements and weight while wearing immersion suits are taken into account.
The operator must ensure that the arrangement and selection of life-saving appliances are based on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safety studies referred to in section 116, in particular any escape and evacuation analysis that takes into account any major accidental events; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the results of the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1).

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that copies of a plan showing the position of all life-saving appliances are posted at the installation, including in the main control centre and in every accommodations area and work area.
For the purpose of subsections (1) and (2), the operator must ensure, with respect to the lifeboats on an installation, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are kept in at least two separate locations, one of which is adjacent to a temporary safe refuge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they have a combined capacity to accommodate the total number of persons on board the installation — and those kept in each location have a combined capacity to accommodate the total number of persons assigned to that location — even in the event that any one lifeboat is lost or rendered unusable; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the installation is a floating platform, those lifeboats that are able to be launched under any credible scenario of angle of heel have a combined capacity to accommodate the total number of persons on board the installation.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the lifeboats are totally enclosed and are fire-protected.
The operator must ensure that each lifeboat is capable of being in continuous communication with each other lifeboat and with other vessels in the area.
The operator must ensure that each lifeboat is equipped with towing devices.

For the purpose of subsections (1) and (2), the operator must ensure that the life rafts on an installation have a combined capacity to accommodate the total number of persons on board the installation.

The operator must verify on a continual basis that the lifeboats, life rafts and other life-saving appliances are available and in a condition to perform as intended and must record the findings resulting from each verification.

An operator must ensure that an installation is designed to facilitate its removal from the offshore area at the end of its design service life and to reduce any risks to safety, adverse effects on the marine environment and interference with navigation and other uses of the sea that may occur during and after its removal.
Subsection (1) does not apply if the Board has approved, in the development plan, the abandonment or an alternative use of the installation.
An operator must ensure that an installation, or any part of it, is transported and positioned

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a manner that does not compromise safety or the protection of the environment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a manner that minimizes interference with and hazards to other activities in proximity to that installation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: under the supervision of a competent third party;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a self-elevating mobile offshore platform, with the legs of the platform secured in accordance with the rules of the classification society that issued the certificate of class required under section 140; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: with the support of vessels that are classified in accordance with section 177.

Subsection.Text: Before an installation, or any part of it, is transported and positioned, the operator must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a risk assessment must be conducted that takes into account

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: personnel requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the towing vessels that will be used, the towing plan, including towing arrangements, and the operating limits of the towing equipment’s components,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the processes and control measures to be implemented to ensure safety and the protection of the environment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: physical and environmental conditions and the ability to reliably forecast those conditions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: any contingency measures to be taken in the event of adverse physical and environmental conditions or the occurrence of any other foreseeable adverse event during transportation and positioning; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a transportation and positioning plan must be prepared that takes into account any requirements of the competent third party referred to in paragraph (1)(c) and, if the installation is a floating platform, the plan must be prepared in accordance with the rules of the classification society that issued the certificate of class required under section 140.

Heading.TitleText: Systems and Equipment: Design, Installation, Commission and Other Requirements

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that any electrical system on an installation is designed to avoid any abnormal conditions and faults that may endanger the installation or, if it is not possible to avoid them, to provide alerts of those conditions and faults and mitigate their effects.

The operator must ensure that all electric motors, lighting fixtures, electrical wiring and other electrical equipment on an installation are safe and reliable under all foreseeable operating conditions.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Device for monitoring insulation level to earth
Subsection.Text: If a primary or secondary distribution system for electrical power, heating or lighting with no connection to earth is used on an installation, the operator must ensure that the system is equipped with a device that continuously monitors the insulation level to earth and produces an audible or visual alarm to indicate abnormally low insulation values.
The operator must ensure that the main electrical power supply on, or to, an installation

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensures continuous availability of power generation and distribution;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: includes at least two power plants or other power supply sources, not including emergency power plants;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of supporting all normal operations without recourse to the emergency electrical power supply required under subsection 126(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of supporting all operations, other than drilling and production, if one of the power plants is out of operation.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the primary circuits from a power plant serving an installation are capable of being shut down from at least two separate locations, one of which must be the site of the power plant.

An operator must ensure that a control system is designed in accordance with the measures referred to in clauses 9(2)(b)(v)(D) and 10(2)(b)(v)(D) that are described in the operator’s safety plan and environmental protection plan, respectively.
The operator must ensure that the control system is designed to meet the following requirements, taking into account human factors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: controlled equipment must not be capable of being inadvertently activated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: controlled equipment must not create a safety or environmental hazard in the event of system failure or shutdown;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the system must have basic diagnostic capability; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the system must be capable of being operated simultaneously from multiple control stations without compromising safety.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that control system hardware is protected from circumstances, including excessive vibration, high electromagnetic field levels, electrical power disturbances and extreme temperatures or humidity levels or other physical and environmental conditions, that could cause mechanical damage to or degradation of the hardware or that could otherwise adversely affect the performance of the system.
The operator must ensure that any wireless remote control system includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a means for error checking to prevent the controlled equipment from responding to corrupt data; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a means for identification coding to prevent a transmitter other than the designated transmitter from operating the equipment.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that all control system functions that are required to ensure safety and are dependent on wireless communication links have an alternative means of control that can be activated without delay and without modification to the control system.

Equipment that is to be operated by a new, repaired or modified control system must not be put into operation until the operator ensures that the control system has been inspected and tested to confirm that it functions as intended.

The operator must ensure that documentation containing an up-to-date description of the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the control systems is readily accessible for consultation and examination.

An operator must ensure that an integrated software-dependent control system whose failure or malfunction would cause a hazard to safety or the environment is maintained to ensure its reliability, availability and security.
The operator must ensure that control measures are implemented to protect the integrated software-dependent system from any threat, including unauthorized access.
The operator must ensure that any software that is a safety-critical element is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: secure, reliable and capable of being updated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designed, commissioned and updated by competent persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: demonstrated to be fit for the purposes for which it is to be used through a testing and validation process that takes into account

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: all foreseeable operating conditions and emergency situations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: system complexity, dependencies and interactions between systems, software failure modes and the level of risk associated with system failure or malfunction.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that no modification to the features of the software is implemented unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the modified software has undergone the testing and validation process referred to in paragraph (1)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the necessary internal approvals for the modification have been obtained, including the approval of the installation manager.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that an installation has an emergency electrical power supply that is independent of the main electrical power supply such that the following systems and equipment continue to function in the event of a failure of the main electrical power supply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: lights at

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: all embarkation and debarkation stations and evacuation points,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all escape routes, temporary safe refuges, service corridors, accommodations area corridors, stairways, exits and personnel lift cars,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all control centres, control stations and areas from which the communication system referred to in section 129 is controlled,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: spaces from which drilling or production equipment, including any equipment that is critical to that equipment’s operation, is controlled,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: spaces where equipment that is related to the emergency shutdown system referred to in section 133 and to the power plants referred to in paragraph 122(4)(b) is located,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: areas where emergency response equipment is stored, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft landing areas and the location of any obstacle to take-off and landing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: hazard detection systems, including the central monitoring system referred to in section 169 and the fire and gas detection system referred to in section 132;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: emergency response and life-saving systems, including life-saving appliances that require electrical power;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the communication system referred to in section 129;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency shutdown system referred to in section 133;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the lights and sound-signalling appliances referred to in section 127;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a floating platform, the pumps and powered watertight doors and hatches that are necessary to stabilize the installation, having regard to the failure modes and effects analysis referred to in subsection 144(5);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a column-stabilized mobile offshore platform, the ballast systems referred to in section 144;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the systems and equipment that are necessary to safely suspend at any time drilling or production that is in progress, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: blowout prevention systems, including the blowout preventer referred to in subsection 68(5),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any disconnectable mooring system referred to in section 148,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any disconnect system referred to in section 150, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: pumping systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any other system or equipment that requires electrical power and that is referred to in the operator’s safety plan referred to in section 9 or its contingency plan referred to in section 11.

Subsection.Text: If the emergency electrical power supply is a mechanically driven generator, the operator must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the installation is equipped with a transitional source of electrical power, unless the generator will automatically start and supply the necessary power in less than 45 seconds from the time the main electrical power supply fails;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the installation is equipped with a self-contained battery system that is designed, on failure or shutdown of both the main electrical power supply and the emergency electrical power supply, to automatically supply sufficient power to operate

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for a period of at least one hour, the lights that are located in any emergency exit route, any escape route, any space where equipment incorporating an internal combustion engine, gas turbine, electric motor, generator, pump or compressor is found, any control centre and any emergency assembly room and at every launching station of life-saving appliances,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for a period of at least one hour, the communication system referred to in section 129 and the general alarm system referred to in section 130, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: for a period of at least four days, the lights and sound-signalling appliances referred to in section 127; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the mechanically driven generator has redundancy in its starting capabilities and a dedicated fuel source.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the emergency electrical power supply together with any transitional source of electrical power and self-contained battery system with which the installation may be equipped are designed and maintained such that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are able to provide the systems and equipment referred to in subsection (1) with an emergency power supply of sufficient capacity, taking into account starting currents and the transitory nature of electrical loads, and sufficient duration to ensure that the systems and equipment can function as intended and to allow for effective management of the installation during an emergency, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to allow for the complete shutdown and evacuation of the installation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to facilitate emergency response and the safe escape, refuge and evacuation of persons or to maintain the integrity of the installation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: to ensure sufficient power so that systems that must operate simultaneously can do so,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a floating platform, to maintain the flotation and stability of the platform, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: to bring a well to a safe state and to maintain it in that state;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: their capacity to provide power to essential systems is not compromised during their maintenance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: they have sufficient redundancy to ensure their reliability and, as far as is practicable, to ensure their functional and physical independence from other essential systems or, if that is not practicable, they are arranged so as not to adversely affect or be adversely affected by the operation of those systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: they are readily accessible.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the emergency electrical power supply, transitional source of electrical power and self-contained battery system referred to in subsection (3) are arranged — or are otherwise protected from mechanical damage and damage caused by fire, explosion and physical and environmental conditions to which they may be exposed — so that they remain capable of fulfilling their intended functions under all foreseeable operating conditions, including, in the case of a floating platform, under the static and dynamic angles of inclination referred to in subsection 136(7).

The operator must ensure that, in the event of a failure of the main electrical power supply, all control centres are alerted by means of an audible and visual signal that the installation is being powered by the emergency electrical power supply.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with the lights and sound-signalling appliances that are required by the Collision Regulations as if that installation were a Canadian vessel to which those Regulations apply, unless compliance with the height and distance requirements of those Regulations is not possible, in which case the lights and appliances must be installed to maximize their audible and visual alerting capabilities for collision avoidance.

An operator must ensure that an installation other than an unattended installation is equipped with radar for identifying hazards in proximity to the installation and that the radar is continuously monitored.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with a communication system that has built-in redundancy and is capable of communicating continuously, including in an emergency, with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: external emergency response teams;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all persons, individually or collectively, at an operations site;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all persons who are in transit to or from an operations site;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all support craft;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: all onshore support centres;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nearby vessels and aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: nearby installations.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that an installation other than an unattended installation is equipped with a radiocommunication system in respect of which the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the system must comply with Part 2 of the Navigation Safety Regulations, 2020 as if the installation were a Canadian vessel to which those Regulations apply;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a technical acceptance certificate must have been issued in respect of the system under the Radiocommunication Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a continuous listening watch and radio log must be maintained.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that any radiocommunication system on an unattended installation meets the requirements referred to in paragraphs (2)(a) and (b).

An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with a general alarm system that is capable of alerting persons on the installation of any hazards to safety or the environment other than fire or gas.
The operator must ensure that the general alarm system is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: operational at all times other than when the system is being inspected, maintained or repaired;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: flagged as being subject to inspection, maintenance or repair, as required; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designed to prevent tampering.

Subsection.Text: If a general alarm system is being inspected, maintained or repaired, the operator must ensure that there is an alternative means of alerting persons of the hazards referred to in subsection (1).

An operator must ensure that an installation that includes process tanks, process vessels and piping is equipped with a gas release system that has a flaring system, a pressure relief system, a depressurizing system or a cold vent system.
The operator must ensure that the design of the gas release system is based on the results of the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1).
The operator must ensure that the gas release system is designed to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: release gas and combustible liquid from an installation in a controlled manner without creating a hazard to safety;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: reduce pressure in the entire process system as quickly as possible while ensuring a safe and controlled release of pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: minimize the effect on the environment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be activated from the main control centre and from control stations that meet the requirements set out in subsection (5); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that oxygen cannot enter the system during normal operations.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the gas release system is designed and located taking into account factors, including physical and environmental conditions, that affect the safe and normal flaring or emergency release of combustible liquid, gases or vapours so that when the system is in operation it does not damage the installation — or any other installation, vessel or support craft in proximity to it — or injure any person.
The operator must ensure that the control stations from which the gas release system is activated are located and spaced so that they remain protected and accessible for safe operation of the system.
The operator must, in respect of any flaring system, ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if an unlit release of gas could produce toxic gas concentrations or gas concentrations of more than 50% of the lower explosive limit of the released gas,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the system has an automatic igniter system that has redundancy in its ignition capabilities, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an open flare system, the system and any associated equipment are designed to ensure a continuous flame; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the system and any associated equipment are designed to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: withstand the radiated heat at the maximum flaring rate,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: prevent flashback, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: withstand all loads to which they may be subjected.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that any vent that is used to release gas into the atmosphere without combustion is designed and located in accordance with the measures referred to in clause 9(2)(b)(vi)(A) and subparagraph 10(2)(b)(vi) that are described in the operator’s safety plan and environmental protection plan, respectively.
The operator must ensure that any liquid, other than water, that cannot be safely and reliably burned at the flare tip of a gas release system is removed from the gas before it enters the flare.
An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with a fire and gas detection system.
The operator must ensure that the fire and gas detection system

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provides continuous, reliable and automatic monitoring functions to allow persons to be alerted to the presence and location of fire and hazardous gas, as well as the concentration and composition of that gas;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as far as is practicable, is functionally and physically independent of other essential systems or, if that is not practicable, is arranged so as not to adversely affect or be adversely affected by the operation of those systems;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: includes an alarm system with audible and visual alarms that are distinct from other types of alarms, that can be heard or seen at the main control centre and in other areas where persons are normally present, that are, on detection of fire or gas hazards, automatically activated and that can also be manually activated; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: allows control measures, including those that are designed to be initiated automatically, to be initiated manually to prevent abnormal conditions from escalating and causing major accidental events.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the design of the fire and gas detection system is based on the results of the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1).
The operator must ensure that the fire and gas detection system is designed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to detect the types of fire and hazardous gas releases identified in the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to detect hazardous gas and smoke in the air intakes of any mechanically ventilated non-hazardous areas; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: such that the means to manually initiate fire and gas alarms are available at or near the office of the installation manager, at the main control centre, at every control station and at any other locations identified in the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1).

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the fire and gas detection system meets the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its detection components must

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: be capable of detecting the types of fire and hazardous gas releases identified in the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1) in the areas in which they are located,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: ensure reliable and early detection, taking into account their response characteristics, redundancy and performance under foreseeable conditions in which detection may be required,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: be rated and maintained for use in the areas in which they are located, as those areas are classified in accordance with the classification system referred to in subsection 113(2), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: include failure and malfunction indicators;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the system and its components must be protected from mechanical damage and damage caused by fire, explosion and physical and environmental conditions to which they may be exposed so that they remain capable of fulfilling their intended functions under all foreseeable operating conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the system must allow for all necessary information to be continuously provided to the main control centre and other strategic locations to permit the management of emergency situations; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the system must be capable of being reset only if the cause of its activation has been resolved.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure, in relation to the testing and maintenance of the fire and gas detection system, that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the system must be capable of being overridden for the purposes of testing and maintenance activities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: override commands and functions must be applied for the shortest amount of time possible and with as few as possible being applied simultaneously; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the testing and maintenance activities must not impair the system beyond what is necessary to undertake those activities and must not impede its functioning.

Subsection.Text: A work permit is required for the testing and maintenance of the fire and gas detection system.
The work permit must set out measures to be taken to manage the effects of overriding the fire and gas detection system.

The operator must ensure that any leak of gas that is detected by the fire and gas detection system or by means of an auditory, olfactory or visual method — including the observation of the dripping of hydrocarbon liquids from an equipment component — is repaired

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately, if the repair is necessary for the purposes of safety or the conservation of petroleum resources; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as the circumstances permit, in any other case.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that an installation has an emergency shutdown system that is capable of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shutting down all potential ignition sources and potential sources of flammable liquids or gases, including by isolating those sources;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: depressurizing all potential sources of flammable liquids or gases other than reservoirs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: preventing abnormal conditions from escalating and causing major accidental events; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: limiting the extent and duration of any major accidental event.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the design of the emergency shutdown system is based on studies, analyses and assessments that identify potential hazards and must assess the risks associated with those hazards, including the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1) and the risk and reliability analysis referred to in section 108.
The operator must ensure that the emergency shutdown system is designed to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: allow for automated and manual activation to ensure effective shutdown;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: allow for the shutdown of any system or equipment to bring it to a safe state, unless the system or equipment has been rated to remain operational in the area in which it is located, as that area is classified in accordance with the classification system referred to in subsection 113(2);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: allow for the selective shutdown of ventilation systems, other than fans that are necessary for supplying combustion air to engines that are required to operate during emergency situations unless gas has been detected in the intake to those engines;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: allow for the isolation of petroleum and flammable fluid inventories, including reservoirs, wells, production systems and pipelines, from ignition sources;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: take into account the size and segregation of petroleum and flammable fluid inventories to limit the quantity of substances released on loss of containment;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: allow for the depressurization and the disposal of hydrocarbon inventories in a safe manner and to a safe location without cold venting;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: allow for the closure of the installation’s subsea and subsurface safety valves and of pipeline safety valves;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: take into account, in relation to all essential systems, the necessary timelines to support the safe escape, refuge and evacuation of persons and to maintain the integrity of the installation; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: take into account the activation of the fixed fire suppression systems required under paragraph 134(4)(a).

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the logic for the emergency shutdown system includes a hierarchy of shutdown levels, action sequences and timelines that are appropriate for the degree of risk posed by the hazards identified in the studies, analyses and assessments referred to in subsection (2).
The operator must ensure, in relation to the emergency shutdown system, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the system is reliable and, as far as is practicable, it is functionally and physically independent of other essential systems or, if that is not practicable, it is arranged so as not to adversely affect or be adversely affected by the operation of those systems;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the system includes an alarm system, with audible and visual alarms that are distinct from other types of alarms, that will automatically activate in the main control centre and at other strategic locations so that all affected persons, having regard to the hierarchy of shutdown levels referred to in subsection (4), are alerted to the emergency shutdown;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: there is continuous monitoring from the main control centre of the system’s status, including, if the system or part of the system is overridden, the extent and duration of the override;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the system and its components are protected from mechanical damage and damage caused by fire, explosion and physical and environmental conditions to which they may be exposed so that they remain capable of fulfilling their intended functions under all foreseeable operating conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the system allows for all information that is necessary to permit the management of emergency situations to be continuously provided to the main control centre and other strategic locations, including information regarding

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the shutdown level and the source of activation of the system,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any shutdown effects that failed to execute on activation of the system, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the status, including failure, of the system’s components;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the system is capable of being activated from multiple manual activation points that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: clearly marked,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: protected against unintentional activation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: located at

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in the case of manual activation points for the highest level of shutdown, the main control centre and other strategic locations, including aircraft landing areas and other embarkation stations, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in the case of all other manual activation points, strategic positions, at least one of which must not be in a hazardous area;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the activation of the system from a manual activation point triggers the general alarm system referred to in section 130;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if any part of the system is operated using a hydraulic or pneumatic accumulator,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the accumulator

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: is located as close as is practicable to the part that it is intended to operate, except if that part is part of a subsea production system, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: has the capacity for a sufficient number of activations to ensure that shutdown can be achieved, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the shutdown valves revert to a fail-safe mode in the event of a failure of the accumulator;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the system is capable of testing both its input and output signal devices and its internal functions to ensure its functioning;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of a failure of the main electrical power supply referred to in subsection 122(4), the system has the capacity to function continuously until the main electrical power supply is restored or all shutdown operations have been concluded;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: in the event that an impairment of the system or any of its components increases the risk to safety or the environment, any other systems that support the emergency shutdown system reverts to a fail-safe mode;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: if two or more installations are connected or if there is temporary equipment that has an emergency shutdown system on an installation,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the emergency shutdown systems of the connected installations are linked so that emergency shutdown signals are transmitted between those systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the emergency shutdown systems of the temporary equipment are linked to the installation’s emergency shutdown system so that emergency shutdown signals are transmitted between those systems, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the logic for the emergency shutdown system of each of the connected installations and of the temporary equipment is re-evaluated and modified, if necessary, to take into account the fact that the emergency shutdown systems are linked, with the logic of the installation’s emergency shutdown system being given priority over that of any temporary equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the system is capable of being overridden or reset only if the cause of its activation has been resolved and there has been local confirmation that the equipment that gave rise to the system shutdown can be safely used; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: override commands and functions are not capable of being unintentionally activated.

Subsection.Text: If the emergency shutdown system is capable of being overridden for the purposes of testing and maintenance activities, the operator must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: override commands and functions must be applied for the shortest amount of time possible and with as few as possible being applied simultaneously; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the testing and maintenance activities must not impair the system beyond what is necessary to undertake those activities and must not impede the system’s functioning.

Subsection.Text: A work permit is required for the testing and maintenance of the emergency shutdown system.
The work permit must set out the measures to be taken to manage the effects of overriding the emergency shutdown system.

In the case of a production installation, the operator must ensure that, if the emergency shutdown system is activated, any subsurface safety valve closes not later than two minutes after the tree safety valve has closed unless a longer delay is justified by the mechanical or production characteristics of the well.
An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with fire protection systems and equipment to control and extinguish fires.

The operator must ensure that the fire protection systems and equipment are designed, selected, operated, inspected, tested and maintained in accordance with the measures referred to in clause 9(2)(b)(vi)(B) that are described in the operator’s safety plan.

The design and selection of fire protection systems and equipment, including suppression agents, must take into account their intended use and the results of the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1).
The operator must ensure that the fire protection systems and equipment include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: automated fixed fire suppression systems that are capable of being manually activated from outside the space that is being protected;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fixed monitors, deluge systems and foam systems;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: manual firefighting systems and equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any redundancies that are necessary to ensure that the systems function in the case of a failure of one of their components.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the fire protection systems and equipment are protected from mechanical damage and damage caused by fire, explosion and physical and environmental conditions to which they may be exposed so that they remain capable of fulfilling their intended functions under all foreseeable operating conditions.

The operator must ensure that an automated fixed fire suppression system is installed in every accommodations area and hazardous area and in any other area that requires such a system based on the results of the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1).
The operator must ensure that at least two dedicated, segregated and independently driven fire pumps supply a dedicated firewater ring main and that each of those fire pumps is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with at least two independent starting devices; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designed to allow for both local and remote control.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the fire pumps are located as far as possible from equipment used for storing and processing petroleum, taking into account the results of the risk assessment conducted under subsection 107(1).

The operator must ensure that the fire pumps and piping and their valves are capable of providing a sufficient supply of firewater to any area on the installation, including if a segment of the firewater ring main is damaged.
The operator must ensure that the firewater system is capable of operating continuously for a minimum of 18 hours.

The operator must ensure that the number and location of fire hydrants and fire hose reels are such that at least two jets of water, not emanating from the same location, can reach any part of the installation where a fire may occur.
In areas where it is not practical to use fire hydrants and fire hose reels, the operator must ensure that portable fire-extinguishing equipment is readily available and accessible.

The operator must ensure that audible and visual alarms will activate at the main control centre on the initiation of any of the automated fixed fire suppression systems or on the loss of any firewater pressure.

If the automated fixed fire suppression system creates a hazard to persons, the operator must ensure that audible and visual alarms automatically activate inside and outside the space that is being protected.
Paragraphs (4)(a) and (b) and subsections (6) to (11) do not apply in respect of unattended installations.
An operator must ensure that boilers and pressure systems are designed in accordance with the measures referred to in clause 9(2)(b)(vi)(C) that are described in the operator’s safety plan.
The boilers and pressure systems must be designed to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevent the occurrence of an abnormal condition that could cause an undesirable event;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevent an undesirable event from causing a release of liquids, gases or vapours;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prevent the ignition of any flammable liquids, gases or vapours that are released;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: safely disperse or dispose of any liquids, gases or vapours that are released;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: prevent the formation of explosive mixtures;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: limit persons’ exposure to fire hazards;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: monitor safe limits of pressure, temperature and fluid levels and reliably protect against exceeding those limits;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: permit the examination of components critical to the pressure system to ensure their continued integrity;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: allow for draining and venting at all stages of operation to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: permit cleaning, inspection and maintenance activities to be carried out safely, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: avoid harmful effects, including water hammer, vacuum collapse, corrosion and uncontrolled chemical reactions;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: prevent the escalation in relation to the boilers and pressure systems of accidental events occurring outside of them; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: limit and mitigate the effects of any loss of containment of the contents of the boilers and pressure systems.

Subsection.Text: The design of boilers and pressure systems must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be based on standards that incorporate safety margins, that conform to good engineering practice and that involve the carrying out of analyses and numerical modelling as necessary to determine the behaviour and failure modes of the boilers and pressure systems under all foreseeable operating conditions, taking into account

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the internal and external pressures to which the boilers and pressure systems are subjected,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: ambient and operating temperatures,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: static pressure and the mass of the contents of the boilers and pressure systems when tested or operated,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: foreseeable dynamic loads and reaction forces and moments resulting from, among other things, piping and its supports and other accessories,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: structural and mechanical integrity threats, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: reactions caused by changes in fluids and other substances contained in the boilers and pressure systems over time, including reactions caused by the products of the decomposition of unstable fluids or substances;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if hazards cannot be eliminated, incorporate safety measures that take into account

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the need for closing and opening devices and devices to indicate their status and to prevent their opening or physical access to them while pressure differential exists,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the need to contain hazardous substances and to mitigate the effects of any hazard related to their release,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the surface temperature of the boilers and pressure systems, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the decomposition of unstable fluids; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be approved by an authorized inspector.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that boilers and pressure systems can withstand all combinations of loads, pressures, temperatures, fluids and substances to which they may be subjected during their design service life.

The operator must ensure that the materials used for the manufacture of boilers and pressure systems are compatible with their operating environment and are chemically resistant to the fluids they contain during their design service life.
The operator must ensure that the following documents and records are obtained from the manufacturer of the boilers and pressure systems:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: documents demonstrating that manufacturing, testing and installation have been carried out in accordance with the design specifications provided for in a quality assurance program that is approved by an authorized inspector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: records of the procedures that were followed in the welding, brazing and non-destructive examination of the boilers and pressure systems, including the results of the welder qualification tests specific to the welding and brazing procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: documents evidencing the qualifications of persons involved in manufacturing, inspection and testing, including welders; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: traceability records for the components of the boilers and pressure systems.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Construction, installation, commissioning, inspection and testing
Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure, before a boiler or pressure system is put into operation, that it has been

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: constructed, installed and commissioned by persons with the necessary experience, training, qualifications and competence to do so safely and in a manner that protects the environment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subjected to any inspections by an authorized inspector and tests by or under the direction of an authorized inspector, including non-destructive examination and proof tests, that are necessary to ensure its integrity and compliance with design specifications.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that a boiler or pressure system is inspected by an authorized inspector and tested by or under the direction of an authorized inspector

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the boiler or pressure system is put into operation following its installation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before the boiler or pressure system is put into operation following any modification or repair to it, including welding; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at any other interval as required by the standards on which the design of the boiler or pressure system is based.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that operating procedures are developed for the boilers and pressure systems that inform users of operating hazards and indicate any special measures to be taken to reduce risks when the boilers and pressure systems are being used, maintained or repaired.
The operator must ensure that any boiler or pressure system is used, maintained and repaired in accordance with the operating procedures referred to in subsection (9).
It is prohibited for any person to alter, interfere with or render inoperative any boiler or pressure system fitting, except for the purpose of adjusting or testing the fitting.
The operator must keep a register of all boilers and pressure systems that includes the following documents and information in respect of each:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: accurate design calculations, technical drawings and design specifications, including evidence of the design approval by an authorized inspector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the standards on which the design of the boiler or pressure system is based;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the boiler or pressure system’s operating limits, including its pressure and temperature ratings;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all documents and records required from the manufacturer under subsection (6);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of each inspection and test referred to in subsection (7) or (8), a record created and signed by the authorized inspector who conducted the inspection that includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of the inspection or test,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: information that identifies the boiler or pressure system that was inspected or tested, as well as its location,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the range of safe pressure and temperature at which the boiler or pressure system may be operated,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a declaration by the authorized inspector who conducted the inspection or who conducted or directed the test as to whether the boiler or pressure system meets the standards that were applied in its design and manufacture,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a declaration by the authorized inspector who conducted the inspection or who conducted or directed the test stating that the boiler or pressure system is fit for the purposes for which it is to be used,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: any recommendations regarding the need for modifications to the maintenance program established under section 159, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other observation relevant to safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of each repair or modification made to the boiler or pressure system.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that a boiler or pressure system is marked with any information that is necessary for its safe installation and operation, including an identifier that permits reference to the documents and records referred to in subsection (6) and the information referred to in paragraphs (12)(e) and (f).

The operator must ensure that all operating procedures developed in accordance with subsection (9) and the register referred to in subsection (12) are periodically verified by the certifying authority.
This section does not apply to any of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a heating boiler that has a heating surface of 3 m2 or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a pressure system that is installed for use at a pressure of one atmosphere of pressure or less;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a pressure vessel that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has a capacity of 40 L or less, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has an internal diameter of

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: 152 mm or less, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: more than 152 mm but not more than 610 mm if the pressure vessel is used for the storage of hot water or is connected to a water pumping system containing compressed air that serves as a cushion;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a refrigeration plant that has a refrigeration capacity of 18 kW or less; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a domestic water and plumbing system.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that any mechanical equipment on an installation

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is designed, selected, located, installed, commissioned, protected, operated, inspected and maintained in accordance with the measures referred to in clauses 9(2)(b)(v)(E) and 10(2)(b)(v)(E) that are described in the operator’s safety plan and environmental protection plan, respectively; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: can operate safely and reliably under all foreseeable operating conditions, taking into account the manufacturer’s instructions.

Subsection.Text: Mechanical equipment must be designed to eliminate hazards to safety or the environment in the following scenarios or, if that is not possible, to mitigate the risks posed by those hazards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: loss of containment of hazardous substances;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: overspeeding and loss of restraint of machinery components with high kinetic energy;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: extreme surface temperatures of the mechanical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: movement of mobile components of the mechanical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: loss of control and integrity of the mechanical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: ignition of potentially explosive atmospheres in hazardous areas from sparks, flames or excessive heat; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: escalation of accidental events.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that controls and manual shut-off devices for mechanical equipment are in a protected and readily accessible location that permits safe operation when an accidental event occurs that renders the equipment inaccessible.
The operator must ensure that the basic operating instructions for an internal combustion engine provide details of stop, start and emergency procedures and are permanently attached to the engine.
The operator must ensure that turbines and internal combustion engines are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: equipped to prevent unintended ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: installed so that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: their supply of combustion air is from a non-hazardous area, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: their exhaust is discharged to a non-hazardous area; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with safety devices — including manual fuel shut-off devices and, unless it would increase safety or environmental risks, automatic fuel shut-off devices — to prevent major damage from overspeeding, high exhaust temperature, high cooling water temperature, low lubricating oil pressure or other foreseeable hazards that could impair the safety of operations.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (5)(c), turbines and internal combustion engines that are critical to emergency response, including emergency generators and fire pumps, need only be equipped with safety devices to prevent major damage from overspeeding.

The operator must ensure that mechanical equipment that is critical to the safety or propulsion of a floating platform will continue to operate safely and reliably at its full rated power under the static and dynamic angles of inclination that are specified in the rules of the classification society that issued the certificate of class required under section 140.
An operator must ensure that all materials handling equipment is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the extent feasible, designed and constructed to prevent the failure of any of its parts, taking into account the conditions under which it is to be operated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the extent feasible, equipped with safety devices that will ensure that any failure of any of its parts does not result in a loss of control of the equipment or of its load or result in any other hazardous situation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: operated taking into account the manufacturer’s instructions and industry standards and best practices.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that all materials handling equipment is marked with its rated capacity and in a manner that identifies its manufacturer and model and that permits reference to any information that is necessary to its safe operation, including information regarding its design, construction, inspection, testing, maintenance and repair.

The operator must ensure that materials handling equipment that is to be used on an installation is inspected and proof-tested by a competent third party in the following situations to determine the equipment’s rated capacity:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment is to be used on the installation for the first time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: repairs or modifications have been made to the equipment’s load-bearing components;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment has been in contact with an electric arc or current; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: there is any other reason to doubt that the rated capacity of the equipment that was most recently certified under subsection (5) or the limitations that were most recently indicated under that subsection continue to be accurate, including as a result of damage sustained by the equipment or modifications made to it.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the inspection and proof-testing is done in accordance with criteria established by the manufacturer or applicable industry design and safety standards, including with respect to the frequency at which the equipment must be inspected and proof-tested to ensure its continued safe operation.

Following the inspection and proof test, the competent third party must certify in writing the rated capacity of the materials handling equipment and must indicate in writing any limitations that must be imposed on its use having regard to physical and environmental conditions.
The operator must ensure that a crane with slewing capability is capable of retaining its slewing and lowering capability in emergency situations.
The operator must ensure that a pedestal crane meets the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it must be equipped with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: appropriate travel-limiting devices for its boom, hoist, blocks and slewing mechanism,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a load-measuring device that has been calibrated in accordance with the manufacturer’s specifications or any calibration standard that is at least as rigorous as those specifications,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a device to indicate its boom extension or load radius, if its rated capacity is affected by the extension or radius,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a device to indicate its boom angle, if its rated capacity is affected by that angle,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a device for accessing anemometer readings, if the load that it is able to safely handle or support is susceptible to being reduced by wind,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: a gross overload protection system, if it is used to move persons or things to or from a floating platform or vessel, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a safe load indicator system that is programmed for different operating modes and includes load and moment measuring devices; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a load chart that specifies the boom angle and the safe working load for each block and for each operating mode, as well as any limitations indicated under subsection (5), must be posted inside its control cab.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that all crane hooks are equipped with spring-loaded latches or other equally effective means of preventing the load from falling off the hook under any operating conditions.

When an aircraft is landing on or taking off from a landing area, it is prohibited to move a crane in the vicinity of the landing area and, if feasible, the person operating the crane must ensure that the crane’s boom is stowed.
The operator must ensure that any materials handling equipment that lifts over 10 tonnes is certified by the certifying authority.

An operator must ensure that a subsea production system is designed, constructed, installed, commissioned, operated, inspected, monitored, tested and maintained in accordance with the measures referred to in clauses 9(2)(b)(v)(F) and 10(2)(b)(v)(F) that are described in the operator’s safety plan and environmental protection plan, respectively.
A subsea production system must be designed so that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the system can avoid foreseeable hazards or revert to a safe state when hazards are imminent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the system supports and seals connections to the well, pipelines, other subsea production systems or other installations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of a loss of control or communication, the system will revert to a safe state;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the failure of a single component of the system cannot cause or contribute to a major accidental event;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: barrier elements in each conduit that carries fluids are reliable, have the necessary redundancy and are arranged to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: prevent uncontrolled flow of well fluids,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: minimize the quantity of fluids released from the conduit in the event of unintended release, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: permit testing of the integrity of the barrier elements without increasing safety or environmental risks;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: subsea equipment can withstand or is protected from any load to which it may be subjected that would result in mechanical damage;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: production risers can withstand or are protected from all hazards and environmental loads to which they may be subjected, other than icebergs; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the blowout preventer is supported by the system during drilling and the tree and any workover or intervention pressure control equipment are supported by the system after completion.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that a riser that is connected to a floating platform that has a disconnectable mooring system or dynamic positioning system is designed to be capable of safely detaching in any foreseeable physical and environmental conditions.
The operator must ensure that, if risers are designed to disconnect in order to avoid foreseeable hazards, riser fluids may be safely displaced by water or isolated.
The operator must ensure that, if a riser is disconnected, its integrity is demonstrated through testing once it is reconnected and before it is brought back into service.
The operator must ensure that a subsea production system is controlled from only one location at any given time.
The operator must ensure that any subsea production system is assessed through a failure modes and effects analysis.
An operator must ensure that any temporary or portable equipment used on an installation is fit for the purposes for which it is to be used.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Assessment of temporary or portable equipment
Subsection.Text: Before any temporary or portable equipment is installed or brought into service on an installation, the operator must ensure that the equipment and its integration with other equipment and systems are assessed to determine their impact on safety-critical elements and on the risk assessment referred to in subsection 24(3).

The operator must ensure that temporary or portable equipment is managed in accordance with the measures referred to in clauses 9(2)(b)(v)(G) and 10(2)(b)(v)(G) that are described in the operator’s safety plan and environmental protection plan, respectively, and in a manner that does not compromise the target levels of safety set out in those plans.

The operator must ensure that temporary or portable equipment that is a safety-critical element is, before being put into operation, verified by the certifying authority to confirm its suitability and safe placement and hook-up.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that a floating platform holds a valid certificate of class issued by a classification society that corresponds to the authorized work or activity to be carried out from the floating platform.

An operator must ensure that a platform that is either founded on the seabed or column-stabilized has a sufficient air gap to operate safely under the maximum environmental load conditions to which it may be subjected.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that a floating platform, whether intact or in a damaged condition, is stable and can be operated safely, having regard to all motions and loads to which it may be subjected, including by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determining the stability and motion response characteristics of the platform using analysis or model testing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determining the critical maximum loads and motions that the platform can withstand;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring that all equipment is fastened to prevent unintended movement; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: monitoring and recording all loads that could affect the motions, stability or inclination of the platform.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that a floating platform has sufficient freeboard to operate safely under the maximum environmental load conditions to which it may be subjected.

The operator must comply with the applicable provisions of the MODU Code and Part B of the IS Code concerning the stability and motion response of a floating platform, which are to be read as mandatory.

If the weight of a floating platform or a self-elevating mobile offshore platform changes by more than 1% of the lightship weight, the operator must ensure that a deadweight survey is carried out at the earliest opportunity and an up-to-date value of the lightship centre of gravity is calculated.

An operator must, in relation to a self-elevating mobile offshore platform, ensure that a site-specific assessment is conducted of the condition of the seabed, including seabed restraint, to ensure that the platform is stable and can be operated safely.
The operator must ensure that a self-elevating mobile offshore platform meets the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it must be equipped with systems to actively monitor

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: hull inclination,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: leg penetration into the seabed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: loads on each of the platform’s legs, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: rack phase differential, if applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
