Paragraph.Text: its jacking mechanisms must be designed so that the failure of a single component does not cause an uncontrolled descent of the platform.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Suspension of operations and well shut-in
Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the works and activities on a self-elevating mobile offshore platform are suspended and that all wells associated with the platform are brought to a safe shut-in condition if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: hull inclination or the rack phase differential exceeds the allowable limits set out in the operations manual in accordance with paragraph 157(3)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: unexplained changes occur in the loads on any of the platform’s legs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: leg penetration into the seabed increases; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other event threatens the stability of the platform.

Subsection.Text: In the case of any of the situations referred to in subsection (3), the operator must ensure that the works and activities on the self-elevating mobile offshore platform remain suspended and that all wells associated with the platform remain in a safe shut-in condition until the cause of the situation has been investigated and corrective measures have been taken.
An operator must ensure that a floating platform is equipped with reliable ballast and bilge systems with the necessary redundancy in their components to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain necessary draught, stability and hull strength under all foreseeable operating conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: return the floating platform to a safe condition from an unintended draught, trim or heel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prevent unintended transfer of fluid within the system;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: empty and fill all tanks that are a part of the system; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: completely and rapidly empty watertight spaces.

Subsection.Text: The operator must comply with the applicable provisions of the MODU Code concerning ballast and bilge systems, which are to be read as mandatory.
In the case of a column-stabilized mobile offshore platform, the operator must ensure that it is equipped with a secondary ballast control station that is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an effective means of communication with other spaces that contain equipment relating to the operation of the ballast system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a ballast pump control and status system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a ballast valve control and status system;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a tank level indicating system;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a permanently mounted ballast schematic diagram;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: heel and trim indicators;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a draught-indicating system;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a system to indicate the available power from the main and emergency electrical power supplies; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a ballast system hydraulic or pneumatic pressure-indicating system.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that a secondary ballast control station is located above the waterline in the final condition of equilibrium after flooding if the floating platform is in a damaged condition.
The operator must ensure that the ballast and bilge systems are assessed through a failure modes and effects analysis before any authorized work or activity is carried out from the floating platform.

Section.MarginalNote: Watertight and weathertight integrity and freeboard

Subsection.Text: The operator must comply with the applicable provisions of the MODU Code and Part B of the IS Code concerning watertight and weathertight integrity and freeboard, which are to be read as mandatory.

The operator must ensure that the floating platform is designed with sufficient watertight subdivision to ensure the preservation of reserve buoyancy and damage stability under all foreseeable conditions.
The operator must ensure that a floating platform

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holds an International Load Line Certificate or an International Load Line Exemption Certificate issued by the government of the state whose flag the platform is entitled to fly, as required under Article 16 of the International Convention on Load Lines, 1966; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is marked in accordance with the certificate.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the arrangement and specification of watertight and weathertight appliances complies with the measures referred to in clause 9(2)(b)(v)(H) that are described in the operator’s safety plan.

The operator must ensure that a floating platform is designed with systems and equipment that provide for the operation, monitoring and indication — both locally and at the ballast control stations — of the opening and closing of watertight doors and hatches and for the detection and provision of alerts of any water ingress into watertight spaces that are not designed to accumulate liquid.
The operator must ensure that the columns of a column-stabilized mobile offshore platform do not have port lights or similar openings.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that a floating platform is equipped with a mooring system or a dynamic positioning system to ensure station-keeping of the platform within its operating limits.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that a mooring system with which a floating platform is equipped is designed, on the basis of analysis and model testing, to ensure

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: safety and the protection of the environment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the stability and serviceability of the floating platform;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the integrity and serviceability of the mooring system components, including any related topside equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the integrity and serviceability of drilling risers, production risers, export risers or any other type of riser;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the necessary redundancy of the mooring system components to enable the floating platform to maintain its position with the loss of a single component or, for a thruster-assisted mooring system, the loss of the most effective thruster or a single failure in the power or control system;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for a thruster-assisted mooring system, the ability of the floating platform to withstand extreme meteorological conditions in the event of a power failure;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the ability of the floating platform to move from its position to avoid accidental events that it is not designed to withstand; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: safe access and safe clearances with respect to subsea and surface components of the installation, any nearby installations, support vessels and evacuation systems.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the excursion limits of a floating platform that is equipped with a mooring system are established on the basis of the analysis and model testing referred to in subsection (1).
The operator must ensure that the floating platform has systems and processes to continuously detect loss of station-keeping or the failure of any mooring system component.
The operator must ensure that mooring line tensions or other indicators of the integrity of the mooring system are monitored and kept within the mooring system’s operating limits.
The operator must ensure that measures to ensure that the mooring system continues to perform in accordance with its design specifications are implemented, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the assessment of the system’s condition, periodically and if it is damaged or if damage to it is suspected; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the making of arrangements for timely repair or replacement in the event of damage or deterioration.

Subsection.Text: If the mooring system with which a floating platform is equipped is disconnectable, the operator must ensure that the system is designed to ensure that disconnection can be accomplished in a controlled manner without creating a risk of drift-off.

The operator must ensure that the disconnectable mooring system is designed and maintained in accordance with the measures referred to in clause 9(2)(b)(vi)(D) that are described in the operator’s safety plan.
The operator must ensure that the disconnectable mooring system includes a primary system and a backup system for disconnection, both of which can be operated locally or from a remote location.
The operator must ensure that a floating platform that is equipped with a disconnectable mooring system is capable of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: safely manoeuvering away under its own power; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: maintaining a safe position and heading while disconnected.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that criteria and procedures for disconnection are developed for all credible disconnection scenarios, including procedures for monitoring environmental conditions and providing alerts for worsening conditions that may require disconnection.
The operator must ensure that the disconnectable mooring system

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of carrying out a planned disconnection after allowing time for the depressurization and flushing of subsea flowlines;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of carrying out an emergency disconnection after allowing time to safely shut in wells and subsea equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: allows for the reconnection to the floating platform of the system and flowlines in an orderly sequence, in the physical and environmental conditions described in the operations manual under paragraph 157(2)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: allows for the resumption of production after the system and flowlines have been reconnected to the floating platform following a planned disconnection;

Subsection.Text: The operator must periodically verify the disconnect capability of the disconnectable mooring system and must record the findings resulting from the verification.
The operator must ensure that the emergency disconnection referred to in paragraph (6)(b) is initiated if the floating platform exceeds the excursion limits established under subsection 147(2).
An operator must ensure that the design of a dynamic positioning system with which a floating platform is equipped

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is based on numerical analysis and model testing to ensure that the floating platform’s position reference and directional control can be maintained within specified tolerances that satisfy design operational requirements in relation to all functional and environmental loads to which the system may be subjected at the floating platform’s intended location;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is based on a failure modes and effects analysis to ensure the segregation and redundancy of safety-critical systems and their components as necessary to maintain the platform’s position in the event that credible scenarios of equipment failure are realized;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: allows the dynamic positioning system to withstand the loss from fire or flooding of all of its components situated in any one watertight compartment or fire subdivision of the floating platform; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: includes systems to monitor the parameters of operability and integrity of the critical systems of the dynamic positioning system and to provide alerts for critical system faults.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the excursion limits of a floating platform that is equipped with a dynamic positioning system are established based on the numerical analysis and model testing referred to in paragraph (1)(a).
An operator must ensure that a floating platform that is equipped with a dynamic positioning system has a disconnect system that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of carrying out a planned disconnection of the floating platform from the seabed after allowing time to prepare the risers and subsea flowlines for the disconnection;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of carrying out an emergency disconnection after allowing time to safely shut in wells and subsea equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: allows for reconnection in an orderly sequence, in the physical and environmental conditions described in the operations manual under paragraph 157(2)(c).

Subsection.Text: The operator must periodically demonstrate by means of a trial or performance test that the disconnect system meets the requirements under subsection (1).
The operator must ensure that the emergency disconnection referred to in paragraph (1)(b) is initiated if the floating platform exceeds the excursion limits established under subsection 149(2).

Section.Text: For any floating platform that is registered outside Canada, the operator must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish a list of all flag State administration decisions and exemptions that apply to the floating platform in relation to any standards adopted by the International Maritime Organization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a risk assessment to identify measures to reduce the safety and environmental risks in relation to those decisions and exemptions to a level that is as low as reasonably practicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establish an action plan to implement the measures referred to in paragraph (b).

Section.Text: The operator must, every time the MODU Code is updated,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: undertake a gap analysis between the criteria in the updated version and the version that applies to the floating platform based on its date of construction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a risk assessment in relation to any gaps identified; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that mitigation measures are implemented, as necessary.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that all installations, including their systems and equipment, are inspected, monitored, tested, maintained and operated to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure safety, the protection of the environment and the prevention of waste; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that they continue to perform in accordance with their design specifications under the operating conditions and maximum loads to which they may be subjected.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that a non-destructive examination of the critical joints and structural parts of an installation is conducted at least once every five years or more often as required to ensure the continued safe operation of the installation.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that if a safety or environmental hazard would result from the failure due to corrosion — including corrosion from exposure to a sour environment — of any equipment, including process vessels, or of any piping, valves, fittings and structural elements that are part of an installation, that corrosion is prevented and managed throughout the life cycle of the installation.

The operator must develop a corrosion management program that sets out the measures that are necessary to prevent critical failures resulting from corrosion-related degradation and to ensure the continued integrity of safety-critical elements.
The program must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identify all safety-critical elements that are susceptible to degradation by corrosion;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide for the analysis that is necessary to determine corrosion degradation mechanisms and the limits and failure modes of the safety-critical elements referred to in paragraph (a), taking into account the physical and environmental conditions and chemicals to which it is foreseeable that the safety-critical elements may be exposed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: include measures to prevent corrosion, as far as is practicable, and to mitigate or protect against the effects of corrosion;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide for the inspection and monitoring of corrosion and of any corrosion protection and prevention systems;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: provide for the collection and analysis of baseline and continuous data to monitor corrosion;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: provide for the continuous assessment, based on the data and analysis referred to in paragraph (e), of the maintenance activities and schedules referred to in paragraph 159(2)(f) to determine whether those activities and schedules are adequate to ensure corrosion management of safety-critical elements and provide for the modification of those activities and schedules, if necessary;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: provide for timely preventive maintenance of any corrosion protection and prevention systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: provide for the timely inspection, monitoring and maintenance of safety-critical elements in accordance with the requirements of the maintenance program referred to in paragraphs 159(2)(e) and (f) and for any necessary repair before the limits established in paragraph (b) are reached.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the program is implemented and periodically updated, taking into account the data and analysis referred to in paragraph (3)(e).

Section.Text: An operator must operate an installation, including its systems and equipment, in accordance with any limitations that are set out in the certificate of fitness under subsection 28(3), with any requirements under this Part and with the operations manual referred to in section 157.

Subsection.Text: An operator must develop an operations manual in respect of each installation that sets out or incorporates by reference the following documents and information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a general description of the installation, including its particular characteristics;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the chain of command and the roles, responsibilities and authorities of persons during normal operations of the installation and in emergency situations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a brief description of the systems and equipment on the installation, including flow sheets and instructions for the assembly, use and maintenance of the systems and equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the operating limits of the installation, including those of its systems and equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the physical and environmental conditions under which the installation and any pipeline can operate without compromising safety or the protection of the environment and the physical and environmental conditions that the installation and pipeline can withstand, taking into account the results of any analyses, tests, numerical modelling or investigations undertaken under subsection 105(2);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the results of the risk and reliability analysis conducted for the purpose of subsection 108(1);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the procedures necessary to ensure the safe operation of the installation, including its systems and equipment, within the limits described in paragraph (d);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the accidental events that would require implementing the contingency plan referred to in section 11, any possible triggers for such events and the measures to be implemented to avoid their occurrence;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the procedures, practices, resources and monitoring measures set out in the contingency plan referred to in section 11;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the criteria for each platform’s minimum penetration into the seabed or for the maximum scour of the platform’s foundation and an indication of the arrangement of the platform’s anchoring system;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the characteristics of each platform’s foundation and its penetration into the seabed or an indication of the arrangement of the platform’s anchoring system, as well as a description of the measures to be implemented to monitor the integrity of the foundation or that of the mooring and anchoring systems;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the criteria to identify meteorological and oceanographic conditions and phenomena that require subsea components and pipelines to be inspected;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: plans that show the arrangement of watertight and weathertight subdivisions;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: details of openings in watertight and weathertight subdivisions, including the location of vents, air pipes and all other means of water penetration, and the means of closure of the compartments, as well as the location of downflooding points;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: a plan that contains information concerning permissible deck loads, variable loading limits and preloading;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: details of all audible and visual signals and alarms used in the communication system referred to in section 129, the general alarm system referred to in section 130, the fire and gas detection system referred to in section 132 and the emergency shutdown system referred to in section 133, as well as details of any colour-coding systems used for the safety of persons on the installation;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: information on any corrosion protection and prevention systems, including their type and location, and any requirements for the safety and maintenance of those systems;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: technical drawings that show

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the arrangement of any deck structure and of the equipment located on it, of all accommodations areas and temporary safe refuges and of any aircraft landing area, including its obstacle-free approach zone,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: sufficient details to permit verification and management, if applicable, of the integrity of hulls, mooring components, primary and critical structures, foundation elements, jacking mechanisms, risers and conductors,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the arrangement of hazardous areas and of any equipment located in those areas, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a fire control and evacuation plan, including

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the location of escape routes, fixed fire suppression systems and life-saving appliances, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the arrangement of barriers that provide passive fire and blast protection and associated equipment, along with a description of those barriers and equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: the operating and maintenance requirements for all the life-saving appliances referred to in section 119;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: information identifying the aircraft that were used for the design of any aircraft landing area on the installation and the maximum weight, size and wheel centres of those aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: any special arrangements in place to facilitate the inspection and maintenance of the installation, including its systems and equipment, and the storage of any crude oil on the installation;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: special precautions to be taken or instructions to be followed when repairs or alterations to the installation, including its systems or equipment, are to be carried out;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: any special operational or emergency requirements and procedures with respect to any systems and equipment that are critical to safety, including the emergency shutdown system referred to in section 133;

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the air gap or freeboard and of the means of ensuring that the requirements under section 141 and subsections 142(2) and 145(1) and (3), as the case may be, are met;

Paragraph.Label: (y)
Paragraph.Text: the number of persons who can be accommodated on the installation during normal operations;

Paragraph.Label: (z)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the main electrical power supply referred to in subsection 122(4) and the emergency electrical power supply referred to in section 126 and any limitations on their operation;

Paragraph.Label: (z.1)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure for periodically documenting the results of all inspections, monitoring, testing and maintenance of the installation’s integrity, including the format and presentation of that documentation; and

Paragraph.Label: (z.2)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure for notifying the Chief Safety Officer and the certifying authority under subsections 162(1) and 170(1) and (2).

Subsection.Text: In the case of a floating platform, the operations manual must also contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the platform’s station-keeping system and its capabilities, taking into account the platform’s operating limits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all procedures for addressing the failure of any component of the station-keeping system that is critical to safety;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the station-keeping system is a mooring system, descriptions of the environmental loads that the moorings can sustain to keep the platform moored in place, the estimated holding power and capacity of the anchors in relation to the soil at the drill site or production site and the physical and environmental conditions in which reconnection of the platform is permitted;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures for addressing an excursion outside of the limits established in the context of the analysis and model testing under subsections 147(2) and 149(2);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description and the limitations of any onboard computer or computer-based control systems used in operations such as ballasting and dynamic positioning and in the platform’s trim and stability calculations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: instructions on how to assess the loading and ballast conditions of the platform to determine its stability and how to manage those conditions to maintain the platform’s stability in accordance with the provisions referred to in subsection 142(3);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: data on the location, type and weights of permanent ballast installed on the platform;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: hydrostatic curves or equivalent data;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a plan that shows the capacities and the centres of gravity of tanks and bulk material stowage compartments;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: tank-sounding tables or curves that show the capacities and the centres of gravity in graduated intervals and the free surface data for each tank;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: stability data that take into account the maximum height of the centre of gravity above the keel in relation to the draught curve and other parameters relevant to the stability of the platform;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the results of any inclining test, or of any lightweight survey together with the inclining test results, and the updated location of the platform centre of gravity following a deadweight survey;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: examples of loading conditions for each mode of operation, together with the means to evaluate any other loading conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: technical drawings that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: show the arrangement and location of all openings that could affect the stability of the platform and their means of closure,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: show the arrangement and operation of the ballast and bilge systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: are accompanied by the operating instructions for the ballast and bilge systems, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: are sufficient in their scope and detail to ensure, in combination with the instructions referred to in subparagraph (iii), that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the necessary draught, stability and hull strength can be maintained under all foreseeable operating conditions, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the floating platform can be returned to a safe condition from an unintended draught, trim or heel; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: a towing arrangement plan, if necessary, and the operating limits of the towing equipment’s components.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a self-elevating mobile offshore platform, the operations manual must also contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any equipment for elevating and lowering the installation and details of any special types of joints and their purpose, including any operating or maintenance instructions for the equipment and joints; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the allowable limits for hull inclination and rack phase differential.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the operations manual is kept up-to-date.

An operator must develop the following programs to ensure the continued integrity of an installation, including its systems and equipment, from the time the installation is commissioned until it is abandoned or removed from the offshore area:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance program referred to in section 159;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the preservation program referred to in section 160; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the weight control program referred to in section 161.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that the programs are implemented and periodically updated.

The maintenance program must set out the inspection, monitoring, testing and maintenance policies and procedures for the installation, including its systems and equipment, that are necessary to ensure safety, protect the environment and prevent waste.
The maintenance program must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include the measures to ensure that the installation, including its systems and equipment, continues to perform in accordance with its design specifications;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: include the measures to ensure compliance with any inspection, monitoring, testing or maintenance requirements under this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: include the performance standards developed by the operator for the installation, including for its systems and equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: take into account the failure modes and mechanisms of safety-critical elements and the causes of their failure;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: include inspection and monitoring activities that occur at a frequency and in a manner to prevent, if practicable, the failures referred to in paragraph (d), or to mitigate the effects of those failures, and to ensure that safety-critical elements are repaired, replaced or modified without delay and in accordance with section 162; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: include predictive and preventive maintenance activities and schedules for each safety-critical element that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are based on the performance standards referred to in paragraph (c),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: take into account the manufacturer’s recommendations and industry standards and best practices,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: specify a minimum frequency for the comprehensive inspection of each safety-critical element, taking into account its condition and the conditions under which it is used,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: for rotating equipment, provide for partial or complete dismantling and inspection at a frequency necessary to maintain the equipment in good condition and to ensure that the equipment’s functionality, availability, reliability and performance are in accordance with its design specifications,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: provide for a periodic maintenance regime for any low running-hour equipment, such as emergency generators, essential generators and fire pumps, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: provide for the management of spare parts so that critical spare parts are available on the installation to ensure the continued functionality, availability, reliability and performance of each safety-critical element in accordance with its design specifications.

Subsection.Text: The preservation program must set out the measures that are necessary to ensure the integrity of equipment that is taken out of service and stored for future use.

The program must provide for the periodic inspection of the stored equipment to verify its integrity and ensure that it is fit for the purposes for which it is to be used if it is brought into service.

Section.Text: The weight control program must set out the measures that are necessary to ensure that the weight and centre of gravity of each installation are kept safely within the installation’s operating limits.

Section.MarginalNote: Safety-critical element — repair, replacement or modification

Subsection.Text: The holder of a certificate of fitness must ensure that the certifying authority and the Chief Safety Officer are notified before a safety-critical element is repaired, replaced or modified and before any equipment that would change the design, performance or integrity of a safety-critical element is brought on board the installation.
The holder of a certificate of fitness must ensure that the approval of the certifying authority is obtained before a safety-critical element is repaired or modified.
The holder of a certificate of fitness must ensure that a safety-critical element that has been repaired or modified is not put into operation until the certifying authority has verified it and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: confirmed that it is fit for the purposes for which it is to be used, can be operated safely without posing a threat to persons or the environment and meets the requirements of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: imposed any limitation on the operation of the installation that is necessary to ensure that the installation meets the requirements referred to in paragraph 28(1)(b).

Subsection.Text: In an emergency, subsections (2) and (3) do not apply if the installation manager considers that the delay required to comply with the requirements under those subsections endangers persons on the installation or the environment.
A safety-critical element that is repaired or modified in an emergency must be verified by the certifying authority in accordance with subsection (3) as soon as the circumstances permit.
This section does not apply in the case of an adjustment made to or the testing of a boiler or pressure system fitting.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the drilling fluid system and associated monitoring equipment provide an effective barrier against formation pressure, ensure safe well operations, prevent pollution and allow for well evaluation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the indicators and alarms associated with the monitoring equipment are strategically located on the drilling rig to alert persons on it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: dedicated personnel provide continuous monitoring, using independent monitoring systems, of parameters that are critical to safe well operations or to the detection of a gain or loss of drilling fluid while the installation is connected to the well and is taking fluid returns.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that every drilling riser is, throughout the duration of a well operation, capable of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing access to the well;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: isolating the well-bore from the sea;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: withstanding the differential pressure of the drilling fluid relative to the sea;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: withstanding the maximum loads to which it may be subjected; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: permitting the drilling fluid to be returned to the installation.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that every drilling riser is supported in a manner that effectively compensates for any loads caused by the motion of the installation, the drilling fluid or the water column.

The operator must ensure that a drilling riser analysis and, in the case of a floating platform that uses a dynamic positioning system, a weak-point analysis of the drilling riser are conducted and that the certifying authority in relation to the installation approves those analyses.
An operator must ensure that a completed development well is equipped with a fail-safe subsurface safety valve that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can be operated from the surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the well is located where permafrost is present in unconsolidated sediments, is installed in the production tubing below the base of the permafrost.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that a completed development well on a fixed platform that has gas-lift, injection or production capabilities in the A-annulus is equipped with an additional fail-safe safety valve on the A-annulus.
The operator must ensure that all fail-safe safety valves are designed, installed, tested, maintained and operated to prevent uncontrolled well flow when they are activated.
An operator must ensure that well tubulars, trees and wellheads are operated in accordance with good engineering practices.
The operator must ensure that any well tubulars, trees or wellheads that may be exposed to a sour environment are capable of operating safely in that environment.

The operator must ensure that the wellhead and tree equipment, including any valves, are designed and maintained to operate safely and efficiently throughout the life cycle of the well under all loads to which the well may be subjected.
An operator must ensure that the equipment used in a formation flow test is designed to safely control well pressure, evaluate the formation and prevent pollution.
The operator must ensure that the rated working pressure of formation flow test equipment at and upstream of the well testing manifold exceeds the maximum anticipated shut-in pressure.
The operator must ensure that all equipment downstream of the well testing manifold is protected against overpressure.
The operator must ensure, in the case of a development well, that the formation flow test equipment includes a downhole safety valve that permits closure of the test string above the packer.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Downhole safety valve — exploratory or delineation well
Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure, in the case of an exploratory well or a delineation well drilled on a geological feature, that a downhole safety valve is installed before a formation flow test is conducted unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it has been demonstrated as part of the formation flow test program referred to in paragraph 63(3)(a) that the level of risk of the proposed alternative arrangement in that program is equivalent to or lower than that of using a downhole safety valve; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Board has approved the test under subsection 63(5).

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that any formation flow test equipment used in testing a well that is drilled with a floating drilling unit has a subsea test tree that is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a valve that can be operated from the surface and automatically closes when required to prevent uncontrolled well flow; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a release system that permits the test string to be hydraulically or mechanically disconnected within or below the blowout preventers.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that a pipeline is designed, constructed, installed, operated and maintained in accordance with CSA Group standard Z662, Oil and gas pipeline systems, as it relates to offshore pipelines.
The operator must ensure that the pipeline system integrity management program required by that standard is implemented and periodically updated.

Heading.TitleText: Monitoring of Installations, Wells and Pipelines

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that an installation is equipped with a central monitoring system in the main control centre to monitor all systems whose failure could cause or contribute to an accidental event or waste.

The operator must ensure that the alarm, safety, monitoring, warning and control functions associated with the systems that are monitored under subsection (1) are managed to prevent reportable incidents and waste.
When a function referred to in subsection (2) is suspended or found to be impaired, the operator must ensure that the use of any related system is also suspended until

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a function that is suspended, that function is returned to service; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a function that was found to be impaired, measures are implemented to offset the risk of a reportable incident or waste.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that all affected persons are informed when a function referred to in subsection (2) is suspended and when it is returned to service.

An operator must, without delay, notify the Chief Safety Officer of any deterioration of an installation, including its systems or equipment, or of a pipeline, well, vessel or support craft if that deterioration could adversely affect safety or the environment.

If an installation, system, equipment, pipeline or part of a well referred to in subsection (1) is within the scope of work referred to in section 31, the operator must also, without delay, notify the certifying authority of the deterioration.

The operator must ensure that any impairment of an installation, including its systems or equipment, or of a pipeline, well, vessel or support craft is rectified without delay if the impairment could adversely affect safety or the environment.
If it is not possible to rectify the impairment without delay, the operator must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a risk assessment to identify risk mitigation measures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: implement those mitigation measures; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the impairment is rectified as soon as the circumstances permit.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (3) and (4) do not apply in respect of safety-critical elements.
An operator must, in respect of an installation on which persons are normally present, ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a support craft that is at a distance from the installation not greater than that required for a return time of 20 minutes is available at all times for emergency response; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whenever an aircraft is landing or taking off, or personnel are working over the side or otherwise exposed to the risk of falling in the water, a support craft is available in the immediate vicinity of the installation and ready to undertake rescue and recovery operations.

Subsection.Text: The support craft referred to in subsection (1) must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: capable of safely providing necessary support functions in the foreseeable physical and environmental conditions prevailing in the area in which it operates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: equipped to supply emergency services, including rescue and first aid treatment, for all personnel on the installation in the event of an emergency; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with a self-righting fast rescue boat that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the requirements under chapter V of the LSA Code,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is capable of being launched and retrieved when it is loaded with a full complement of persons and equipment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is ready for deployment in the event of an emergency.

Subsection.Text: If the support craft is located at a distance that exceeds the distance referred to in paragraph (1)(a), both the installation manager and the person in charge of the support craft must log that fact and the reason why the distance or time was exceeded.

During any activity or situation referred to in paragraph (1)(b), or any other activity or situation that presents an increased level of risk to the safety of the installation, the vessel master must, under the direction of the installation manager, keep the craft in close proximity to the installation, maintain open communication channels with the installation and be prepared to conduct rescue operations.

Section.Text: An operator must, in respect of any vessel that is used in a geoscientific program, geotechnical program, environmental program, diving project or construction activity, ensure that a rescue boat is available and ready for use in the event of an emergency.

Subsection.Text: A support craft must not enter the safety zone around an installation or around a vessel that is engaged in a geoscientific program, geotechnical program, environmental program or diving project without the consent of the installation manager or the person in charge of the operations site.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Notice to approaching aircraft or vessel
Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that persons who are in charge of an aircraft or vessel that is approaching the safety zone are notified of the safety zone boundaries and of any hazards within that zone that relate to the operator’s installation or vessel.

The safety zone around an installation consists of the area within a line that encloses the installation and is drawn at a distance of 500 m from the outer edge of the installation or, if any component of the installation extends beyond that edge, from the outer limit of the component that extends furthest from that edge.

The safety zone around a vessel referred to in subsection (1) consists of the area within a line that encloses the vessel and any of its attached equipment and is drawn at a distance that minimizes risks to safety, the environment and property located nearby, including fishing gear or fishing vessels.

An operator must ensure that the aircraft landing area on an installation or vessel and the equipment that is used in that area or that otherwise supports the take-off or landing of aircraft are designed to ensure safety and the protection of the environment and to prevent incidents or damage resulting from the use of aircraft.
The operator must ensure that the landing area

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has an obstacle-free take-off and approach area and is oriented relative to prevailing winds;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: can withstand all functional loads imposed by aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: can accommodate aircraft of expected sizes;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: has emergency response and firefighting equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: has conspicuous markings and signage;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: has adequate lighting, including in reduced visibility conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: has monitoring and status light systems and communication and meteorological equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: is readily and safely accessible, including from the accommodations areas and from any temporary safe refuge; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a landing area on an installation, is equipped with fuel storage tanks.

Subsection.Text: The operator must ensure that any fuel storage tanks that are in proximity to a landing area are stored safely and protected from damage, impact and fire.

Section.Text: The operator must ensure the establishment of procedures associated with the support of aircraft operations, including procedures for emergency response, and of a training program for personnel for those purposes.

An operator must ensure that, before the start of any operations that require the use of an aircraft, the aircraft service provider has accepted in writing all conditions with respect to the use of the equipment in any landing area, the procedures associated with the support of aircraft operations, including the procedures for emergency response, and the training program for personnel in respect of those matters.

An operator must ensure that any support or construction vessel to be used in conjunction with an installation holds a valid certificate of class issued by a classification society according to the work or activity to be carried out by it.

Heading.Label: PART 12
Heading.TitleText: Notice, Records, Reports and Other Information for Authorized Works and Activities

Section.Text: In this Part, shotpoint means the surface location of a seismic energy source.

Subsection.Text: An operator must notify the Board of a reportable incident as soon as the circumstances permit, but not later than 24 hours after becoming aware of the incident.
The operator must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any reportable incident is investigated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person who conducts the investigation includes in their investigation report the root causes of the reportable incident, the contributing factors, measures to be implemented to prevent its recurrence and any other relevant information; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the investigation report is submitted to the Board not later than 14 days after the day on which the reportable incident occurred.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that any records that are necessary to support operational requirements and the requirements of these Regulations are readily accessible to the Board for examination.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that records are kept of all information — including the following — that is critical to safety, the protection of the environment or the prevention of waste:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: information on the location and movement of support craft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information on reportable incidents;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information on emergency drills and exercises;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: information on the quantities of consumable substances at any operations site;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: data resulting from any required observation of wildlife;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: information on verification, inspection, monitoring, testing, maintenance and operating activities;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: information on the status of all systems and equipment identified in the safety plan as being critical to safety or in the environmental protection plan as being critical to the protection of the environment, including any test result indicating that the systems or equipment are not functioning as intended and information on any equipment failure that has led to an impairment of any of those systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: information on the physical and environmental conditions observed and forecasted under section 42.

Subsection.Text: The operator must retain the records referred to in subsection (1) for the following periods:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) and (e) to (g) and those referred to in paragraph (1)(h) regarding forecasted conditions, five years after the day on which the record is created;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in paragraphs (1)(b) and (c),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: five years after the day on which the drill or exercise is carried out, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 10 years after the day on which the reportable incident is reported;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in paragraph (1)(d), for as long as the consumable substance is at the operations site; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in paragraph (1)(h) regarding conditions observed, for the duration of the authorized work or activity.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that a safety report that relates to an authorized work or activity conducted in a given calendar year is submitted to the Board within 90 days after the day on which the work or activity is concluded or suspended or, in the case of a work or activity that will continue into the following calendar year, that a safety report that relates to the work or activity conducted in the preceding calendar year is submitted to the Board not later than March 31 of that following calendar year.
The safety report must contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description and analysis of the efforts undertaken to improve safety;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of the operator’s safety performance during the applicable calendar year, including with respect to the objective of reducing safety risks;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of the safety measures and actions taken to mitigate the effects of any reportable incident, as well as of their effectiveness and any adjustments made for their continued improvement; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of any emergency response drills and exercises relating to safety that were completed.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that the Board is made aware, at least once a year, of any report containing relevant information regarding applied research work or studies that the operator has participated in, funded or commissioned concerning the operator’s authorized works and activities in relation to safety, the protection of the environment or resource management and must ensure that a copy of the report is submitted to the Board on request.

When any geoscientific program, geotechnical program or environmental program is commenced, concluded, suspended or cancelled by an operator, the operator must, without delay, notify the Board in writing of the date of the commencement, conclusion, suspension or cancellation of the program.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that weekly reports are submitted to the Board on the status of field work carried out in relation to any geoscientific program, geotechnical program or environmental program from the commencement of the program until its conclusion, suspension or cancellation.
The weekly status reports must contain the following documents and information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the program number assigned by the Board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information identifying, and indicating the current location and status of, all operations sites and support craft used in the program;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: key dates of the works and activities under the program, in particular their commencement, suspension and completion dates,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the works and activities carried out during the preceding week, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the quantity of data collected, broken down by data acquisition technique,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: information identifying and indicating the location of data collection points, lines or areas,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a schedule indicating each type of work or activity carried out under the program, as well as any period in which data acquisition was delayed or interrupted, along with a summary of the causes of that delay or interruption, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of any failure to comply with a condition of the authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: maps illustrating, in relation to the proposed data acquisition plan referred to in subparagraph 8(i)(iii), the portion of the data acquisition that has been completed, the portion that was completed in the preceding week and the portion that remains to be carried out;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an indication of the total number of persons involved in the program who, during the preceding week, were at, or transferred to or from, the operations sites and, if applicable, the means by which they were transferred;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of any communications or interactions that occurred during the preceding week concerning program activities between persons associated with the program and persons associated with fishing activities;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of emergency drills and exercises that were completed and reportable incidents that occurred during the preceding week;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: an indication of the quantities of consumable substances that are critical to safety that are currently at each operations site;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: all wildlife observation data from the preceding week that were required to be recorded under paragraph 181(1)(e);

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of the verification, inspection, monitoring, testing, maintenance and operating activities that are critical to safety that were carried out during the preceding week; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any measures taken during the preceding week to avoid disturbing wildlife or interfering with fishing activities or any other uses of the sea.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that an environmental report that contains the following documents and information is submitted to the Board within 90 days after the day on which a geoscientific program, geotechnical program or environmental program is concluded or suspended:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the general physical and environmental conditions under which the program was conducted and, if applicable, a description of ice management activities and non-productive time caused by meteorological or ice conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of program performance in relation to the environment, including with respect to the objective of reducing environmental risks;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of environmental protection measures and actions that were taken to mitigate the effects of any reportable incident, as well as of their effectiveness and any adjustments made for their continued improvement;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of any emergency response drills and exercises for the protection of the environment that were completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: all wildlife observation data that were required to be recorded under paragraph 181(1)(e).

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that a final operations report, final data processing report and final interpretation report are submitted to the Board with the acquired data referred to in subsection (5), as applicable, within 12 months after the day on which any geoscientific program, geotechnical program or environmental program is concluded, unless a longer period has been agreed to in writing by the Board.
The final operations report must contain the following documents and information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the program number assigned by the Board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the title, author and date of the report;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an executive summary and table of contents;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the operator, contractors and any interest owner, as defined in section 47 of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of all operation sites and any support craft used for the program;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the program, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: key dates, in particular its commencement, suspension and completion dates,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the equipment used,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the operational methods employed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the number of persons who were involved in the program, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the quantity of data collected, broken down by data acquisition technique;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: location maps illustrating details of the data acquisition activities carried out under the program, including the identification and location of data collection points, lines or areas and the type of data acquired;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: location maps illustrating the boundaries of each area covered by the program and any portion of those areas that is subject to an interest, as defined in section 47 of the Act, as well as the identification number of each such interest;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a schedule that specifies the type and duration of all program activities and includes any period in which data acquisition was delayed or interrupted;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: an indication as to the accuracy of the navigation system and of the positioning and survey systems, as well as the parameters and configuration of both the energy source and recording system; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: shotpoint maps, track plots, flight lines with numbered fiducial points, gravity station maps, location maps for any samples or core holes, copies of any photographs and a list of any videos.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Content of final data processing report
Subsection.Text: The final data processing report must contain the following documents and information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the documents and information referred to in paragraphs (2)(a) to (d), (g) and (k);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the program, including the quantity of data collected, broken down by data acquisition technique; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the geoscientific data acquired, including the data processing sequence and parameters.

Subsection.Text: The final interpretation report must contain the following documents and information, as applicable:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the documents and information referred to in paragraphs (2)(a) to (e);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: bathymetric or topographic maps compiled from the data collected;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description and interpretive maps of the acquired data, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: time and depth structure and isopach maps, velocity and residual velocity maps and seismic attribute maps,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: final Bouguer gravity maps and any residual or other processed gravity maps,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: final total magnetic intensity contour maps and any residual, gradient or other processed magnetic maps,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: final controlled-source electromagnetic resistivity maps,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: surficial maps generated from any seabed, geohazard or pipeline route survey, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: any geological maps;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description and analysis of the interpretation of the data with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: geological and geophysical correlations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: correlations between gravity, magnetic, seismic and controlled-source electromagnetic data, including correlations to any data acquired during previous surveys,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of seabed surveys, the geophysical correlation between shallow seismic data and data from cores and geotechnical boreholes,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: corrections or adjustments that were applied to the data during processing or compilation,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the velocity information that the operator used in a time-to-depth conversion,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: cores and samples,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: other geoscientific and geotechnical analyses, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: geohazards; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: synthetic seismograms,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: seismic modelling studies that use synthetic seismograms,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: vertical seismic profiles at wells that were used in the interpretation of the data,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: amplitude versus offset studies,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: seismic inversion studies, if any, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: any other seismic studies related to the program.

Subsection.Text: The following acquired data must accompany the final reports, as applicable:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: time-stamped track plot, shotpoint and sample location data;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: bathymetric data;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all final processed seismic data for each 2-D seismic line in time and depth;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all final processed 3-D volumes and each line generated from that volume in time and depth;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any vertical seismic profiles, synthetic seismograms, amplitude versus offset data and seismic inversion data;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of any seabed, geohazard or pipeline route survey,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: processed high-resolution data for each line,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: digital location maps for any samples,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any photographs and videos, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: sub-bottom profiler and side-scan sonar data;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an environmental program, any photograph, video or other graphic information that is relevant and contributes to the interpretation of the final data and the drafting of the final report;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a gravity or magnetic survey, a series of gravity and magnetic profiles across all gravity and magnetic surveys; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of controlled-source electromagnetic data, final processed cross-sections on all receiver lines, curves from all receivers and all 2-D and 3-D final models generated.

Subsection.Text: The operator must incorporate into any map referred to in paragraph (4)(b) that is included in a final interpretation report any data previously collected by the operator that are related to the area covered by the map and that are of a type similar to the data from which the map was produced.

Section.MarginalNote: Exception — data made available to public

Subsection.Text: An operator that has conducted a geoscientific program, a geotechnical program or an environmental program need not submit a final interpretation report if the data acquired from the program are made available to the public for purchase or for use under licence.

If the operator ceases to make data available for purchase or use under licence, the operator must ensure that, within 12 months after the day on which the operator ceased to make the data available, the final interpretation report is submitted to the Board.

A purchaser of data referred to in subsection 188(1) that were acquired in an area that is subject to an interest, as defined in section 47 of the Act, must submit to the Board a final interpretation report that contains the documents and information referred to in subsection 187(4), as applicable, if the costs of the purchase of the data are to be credited against a deposit or other costs in relation to the interest.

If the purchaser has reprocessed or reinterpreted the data, and if the costs of the reprocessing or reinterpretation are to be credited against a deposit or other costs of the interest, the purchaser must submit to the Board, with the acquired data referred to in subsection 187(5), as applicable, a final data processing report that contains the documents and information referred to in subsection 187(3) and a final interpretation report that contains the documents and information referred to in subsection 187(4), as applicable.
The reports and data required under subsections (1) and (2) must be submitted by the purchaser to the Board before the costs referred to in those subsections are credited.

A person who has submitted a report referred to in this section must, in respect of data that pertain to shotpoints or the location of stations, notify the Chief Conservation Officer, without delay, of any errors or omissions identified in or corrections made to the data after the report is submitted.

Section.Text: When submitting any information to the Board about a well, pool, zone or field under these Regulations, an operator must refer to each by the name given to it under section 59 or paragraph 60(b), as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that a copy of the final results, data, analyses and schematics obtained from any well operation, including those obtained as a result of the following activities, is submitted to the Board:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the testing, sampling and pressure measurements that are conducted as part of the field data acquisition program referred to in section 13 and the well data acquisition program referred to in section 18, as well as any evaluation, testing and sampling of formations that is conducted under section 62; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any verification conducted under paragraph 71(2)(a) and any segregation test conducted under paragraph 71(2)(b).

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the Board, the operator must ensure that the copy is submitted within 60 days after the day on which the activity that gave rise to the results, data, analyses or schematics is concluded.
An operator must ensure that a survey, certified by a person licensed under the Canada Lands Surveyors Act, is conducted to confirm the location of any well and production installation.
The operator must ensure that a copy of the survey plan is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: filed with the Canada Lands Survey Records; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submitted to the Board.

Subsection.Text: The records that must be kept under section 181 include, in the case of an operation involving drilling or production, records containing the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of any assessment of the efficacy of a spill-treating agent under paragraph 11(4)(a),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the assessment, including any oil samples used, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of any tests conducted for the assessment and their results;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information concerning the inspection of any installation and its equipment or a pipeline for corrosion and erosion and any resulting maintenance activities carried out;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the pressure, temperature and flow rate data obtained from compressors and from systems and equipment used for treatment and processing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: information concerning the calibration of meters and other instruments on an installation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: information concerning the testing of subsea, surface and subsurface safety valves;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: information concerning the status of each well and the status of well operations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a floating platform, information concerning all loads that could affect the motions, stability or inclination of the platform, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: data, observations, measurements and calculations related to its stability and station-keeping capability, including records of all of its movements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the results of all tests and analyses conducted to assess its stability and station-keeping capability,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of every change in relation to its weight, its centre of gravity or the weight or distribution of temporary or portable equipment on it that may affect its stability, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the verification of the disconnect capability of any disconnectable mooring system;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of boilers and pressure systems, the documents and information referred to in paragraphs 135(12)(d) to (f);

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: information concerning each formation leak-off test and formation integrity test conducted under section 70;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the findings resulting from the verifications of temporary safe refuges required under subsection 117(3); and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the findings resulting from the verifications of the availability and condition of life-saving appliances required under subsection 119(11).

Subsection.Text: The operator must retain the records referred to in subsection (1) for the following periods:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in paragraph (1)(a), for as long as the spill-treating agent is approved for use;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in paragraphs (1)(b) to (f), subparagraph (1)(g)(iv) and paragraphs (1)(i) to (k), five years after the day on which the record is created;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in subparagraphs (1)(g)(i) to (iii), for the life of the floating platform; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the records referred to in paragraph (1)(h), five years after the day on which the boiler or pressure system is taken out of service.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that a daily production record is kept in respect of a field in which a pool or well is located until the field is abandoned and, at that time, must offer to submit the record to the Board before destroying it.
The daily production record must contain, with respect to each day, the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: information concerning the calibration of meters and other instruments referred to in paragraph 193(1)(d);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any measurements obtained under section 74;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the manner in which any fluids were disposed of, including through venting, burning or flaring, or transported for processing, whether through offloading or a pipeline; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other information relating to the production of petroleum and other fluids from each pool or well.

Section.MarginalNote: Formation flow test records and report
Section.Text: An operator must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of exploratory wells and delineation wells, a record of formation flow test results is submitted to the Board on a daily basis; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of all wells, a formation flow test report is submitted to the Board as soon as the circumstances permit after each formation flow test.

Subsection.Text: An operator must ensure that interim evaluations of a pilot scheme referred to in section 81 are reported to the Board in writing at the intervals referred to in paragraph 81(2)(b).
On completion of the pilot scheme, the operator must ensure that a report is submitted to the Board that contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the results of the scheme and supporting data and analyses; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operator’s conclusions as to the potential of the scheme for application to full-scale production.

Section.Text: An operator must ensure that the following reports are submitted to the Board on a daily basis:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a daily operations report that contains

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the works and activities that were carried out on the installation on the previous day and the current status of those works and activities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the works and activities that are expected to be carried out on the installation on the day on which the report is submitted,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a summary of the verification, inspection, monitoring, testing, maintenance and operating activities critical to safety that were carried out on the previous day,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a summary of the physical and environmental conditions that were observed under section 42 on the previous day,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a summary of the information referred to in paragraph 193(1)(g) that was obtained on the previous day, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: any other information that is necessary to indicate the status of operations on the installation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a daily drilling report that contains

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the daily and cumulative costs of operating the installation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all well and casing data obtained on the previous day,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the properties of the drilling fluid and all drilling fluid gas readings from the previous day,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a summary of any directional and deviation surveys carried out the previous day,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the formations encountered on the previous day,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the results of any blowout preventer test carried out on the previous day and the date of the most recent test, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the results of any formation leak-off tests or formation integrity tests referred to in section 70 that were carried out the previous day;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a daily geological report, consisting of well and field data acquired the previous day through the programs referred to in sections 13 and 18 , geological assessments made the previous day and any other information that is relevant to those assessments; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a production installation, a daily production report that contains a summary of the information referred to in paragraphs 193(1)(a) to (c) in relation to the previous day and a summary of the daily production record referred to in section 194.
